children.name: Eigenspaces, Eigen Vectors, Orthogonality, Orthonormal, Dot products, Grahm Schmidt Theorem

fields: In what notation is a basis written?

Set notation using set notation {} with basis vectors written as column vectors.
Here is an exaple for vectors a,b, and c.
[$]\left \{ \begin{bmatrix}
a_{1}\\ 
\vdots \\ 
a_{n}
\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}
b_{1}\\ 
\vdots \\ 
b_{n}
\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}
c_{1}\\ 
\vdots \\ 
c_{n}
\end{bmatrix} \right \}[/$]

[$]S^\perp = RREF\left ( S^T \right )[/$]
The result is a set of column vectors.
Orthogonal Projection of W onto V

children.name: LInear Transformations, Determinants, Subspaces, and Coordinate Systems

fields: A set of vectors W in [$]\mathbb{R}^n[/$] is called a subspace of [$]\mathbb{R}^n[/$] if it has the following three properties:

1. The zero vector belongs to W.
2. Whenever u and v belong to W, then u + v belongs to W.
(In this case, we say that W is closed under (vector) addition.)
3. Whenever u belongs to W and c is a scalar, then cu belongs to W.
(In this case, we say that W is closed under scalar multiplication.)

1. RREF the Matrix
2. The rank must equal the number of columns for the matrix to be one to one.
(Another way to say linearly indipendent)

1. RREF the Matrix
2. The rank must equal row count.

The dimension or row count of vector.
ex.[$]\begin{bmatrix}
 x_{1}\\ 
 x_{2}\\
x_{3}
\end{bmatrix}[/$]
A linearly indipendent span that is also a generating set for a subspace.

The set of the span of the free vaialbes of A
1. RREF Matrix A
2. Set the result to Ax=0.

null[$]A=\left \x\in \mathbb{R}^{n}| Ax=0 \right \}
[/$]

Null Space is a subspace containing the Free Variables of A

Span of the set of columns of Matrix A written as Vectors.
1. express all columns as a set of vectors using set braces ex. col[$]A={[a],[b],[c]}[/$]

Column space is a subspace containing the columns of A

The set of the span of non-zero rows of A.
1. express all non-zero rows as a set of vectors using set braces ex. row[$]A={[a],[b],[c]}[/$]

Row Space is a subspace containing the non-zero rows of A
The largest set of vectors that can be used to create the rest of a set.
A generating set of [$]\mathbb{R}^{n}[/$] has how many vectors?
A linearly independent set of [$]\mathbb{R}^{n}[/$] has how many vectors?
A basis set of [$]\mathbb{R}^{n}[/$] has how many vectors?
How to find the Basis of a matrix.

1. RREF the matrix
2. The bassis is the set of vectors that make up whatever you are finding.
ex. The Basis of a vector are the vectors that ocupy the pivot columns.
ex. the Basis of a null space are the non pivot vectors that make up the set of Ax=0
Given the coordinate vector [$]\left [ u \right ]_{B}[/$] and set [$]B[/$] where [$]B[/$] is the basis. What is [$]u[/$] with respect to the basis.
Given the vector [$]u[/$] and the basis [$]B[/$] what is the coordinate vector [$]u[/$] with respect to [$]B[/$] or [$]\left [ u \right ]_{B}[/$]?

1. Create an augmented matrix of [$]B[/$] and [$]u[/$]. ex. \left [ B | u \right ]
2. Set the augmented matrix to RREF.
3. [$]u[/$] will be transformed into [$]\left [ u \right ]_{B}[/$]

Alternatively: [$]\left [ u \right ]_{B}=B^{-1}u[/$]
What is the determinant of an upper triangular or lower triangular matrix?
The product of the main diagonal entries.
If the determinant is zero is the matrix invertible?
What are some other terms for finding a determinant?
How do you compute a Determinant using elementary row operations?

1. Reduce the matrix to an upper triangular or lower triangular matrix.
2. The product of the diagonals is the determinant of the matrix.
What happens to the determinant of the matrix if two rows are switched?
The sign of the result of the determinant is switched.

The standard matrix is the coeficent matrix C of the Transformation matrix T as shown below.
[$]T\begin{bmatrix}
x_{1}\\ 
\vdots \\
x_{n} 
\end{bmatrix}=
\begin{bmatrix}
a_{11}x_{1} & \cdots  & a_{1n}x_{n}\\ 
\vdots & \ddots  & \vdots\\ 
 a_{m1x_{1}}& \cdots & a_{mn}x_{n}
\end{bmatrix}[/$]
[$]C=\begin{bmatrix}
a_{11} & \cdots  & a_{1n}\\ 
\vdots & \ddots  & \vdots\\ 
 a_{m1}& \cdots & a_{mn}
\end{bmatrix}[/$]

Exchanging one row for another and vise versa.

[$]\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 & 3\\ 
4 & 5 & 6\\ 
7 & 8 & 9
\end{bmatrix}
R_{1} \leftrightarrow R_{2}
\begin{bmatrix}
4 & 5 & 6\\ 
1 & 2 & 3\\ 
7 & 8 & 9
\end{bmatrix}[/$]

Multiplying a row by a scalar and replacing that row with the result.

[$]\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 & 3\\ 
4 & 5 & 6\\ 
7 & 8 & 9
\end{bmatrix}
2R_{1} \rightarrow R_{1}
\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 4 & 6\\ 
4 & 5 & 6\\ 
7 & 8 & 9
\end{bmatrix}[/$]

Adding or subtracting one row from another and replacing one of the rows with the result.

[$]\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 & 3\\ 
4 & 5 & 6\\ 
7 & 8 & 9
\end{bmatrix}
R_{3} + 2R_{1}  \rightarrow R_{3}
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 & 3\\ 
4 & 5 & 6\\ 
9 & 12 & 15
\end{bmatrix}[/$]

Procedure to derive reduce row echelon form 
by using elementary row operations

For any matrix A, the rank of A is
the number of nonzero rows in the
reduced row echelon form (RREF) of A.

Rank(A) is the number of pivot columns in matrix A

Rank is also referred to as a count of the number of pivots in a matrix.

For any matrix A, the nullity of A,
denoted nullity(A) is the number of pivots subtracted from the column count.

Nullity(A) is the number of nonpivot columns in matrix A.

Columns - Rank = Nullity

For an mxn matrix A:

The columns of A are linearly independent if:

Rank(A) = n (Column Count)

Nullity(A) = zero

There is a pivot position in each column.
How do you check for consistency

The RREF of the augmented matrix
[ A | b] has no row of the form
[0 0 â€¦ 0 | c ] where c not equal to 0.

ex. [0 0 0|1] is inconsistent.
How does Rank relate to the number of solutions of Ax=b?

If Ax =b is the matrix of a consistent system
of linear equations:

There is a unique solution if the rank is equal to the number of columns of the matrix.
How does nullity relate to the number of solutions in Ax=b?

If Ax=b is the matrix of a consistent system
of linear equations:

Ax=b has a unique solution if and only if
nullity(A) = 0.

Ax=b has infinitely many solutions if and
only if nullity(A) > 0.

Matrix multiplication requires you multiply the Columns of A by the Rows of B adding the result one of the columns of the resulting matrix.

[$]A=\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2\\ 
3 & 4
\end{bmatrix}B=\begin{bmatrix}
1 \\
2
\end{bmatrix}
[/$]
[$]AB=\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2\\ 
3 & 4
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
1 \\
2
\end{bmatrix}[/$]
[$]AB = 1\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
3
\end{bmatrix}+ 2\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
4
\end{bmatrix}[/$]
[$]AB=\begin{bmatrix}
5\\
11
\end{bmatrix}
[/$]

An nxn matrix A is invertible if there is an nxn
matrix B such that [$]AB = BA = I_{n}[/$]
If [$]A[/$] is invertible, then [$]A^{T}[/$] is invertible and [$](A^{T})^{-1}= (A^{-1})^{T}[/$]
An elementary matrix [$]E[/$] is a identity matrix [$]I_{n}[/$] that has had elementary row ooperations performed on it.
The system has a unique or infinite number of solutions.

Let [$]A[/$] and [$]B[/$] be nxn matrices.

[$]A[/$] is similar to [$]B[/$] iff there is an invertible matrix [$]P[/$] such that [$]B = P^{-1}AP[/$]
